# set seed

# fontawesome

# magick
dev.off <- function() {
  invisible(grDevices::dev.off())
}
# conflicted
library(conflicted)
conflict_prefer("filter", "dplyr")
# xaringanExtra
library(xaringanExtra)
xaringanExtra::use_panelset()
xaringanExtra::use_slide_tone()
xaringanExtra::use_logo(
  image_url = "fig/INFOR_FullColor_RGB.png"
)
# output number of lines
hook_output <- knitr::knit_hooks$get("output")
knitr::knit_hooks$set(output = function(x, options) {
  lines <- options$output.lines
  if (is.null(lines)) {
    return(hook_output(x, options)) # pass to default hook
  }
  x <- unlist(strsplit(x, "\n"))
  more <- "..."
  if (length(lines) == 1) { # first n lines
    if (length(x) > lines) {
      # truncate the output, but add ....
      x <- c(head(x, lines), more)
    }
  } else {
    x <- c(more, x[lines], more)
  }
  # paste these lines together
  x <- paste(c(x, ""), collapse = "\n")
  hook_output(x, options)
})

# Why R `r fontawesome::fa("r-project")`?

- CLI == fully accessible via keyboard.

- Rmd -> reproducibility -> accessibility.

- Accessible open-source packages.

???
Despite some challenges,

Why R?

As opposed to point-and-click UI, R is a command-line env.

This means that you can everything within terminal console using keyboard only.

Good benefit for keyboard users.

Rmd is a plain text. can be written with any text editor.

---
# Accessible Packages

- [{gt}](https://github.com/rstudio/gt): data.frame and tibble.

- [{BrailleR}](https://github.com/ajrgodfrey/BrailleR): histogram, barplot, and boxplot.

- [{sonify}](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/sonify/): scatter plot and line chart.

- [{rmarkdown}](https://github.com/rstudio/rmarkdown): Swiss army knife for accessibility.

- [{shiny}](https://github.com/rstudio/shiny): interactive navigation.

???
Accessible packages

# Data Verbalization

---

# Alt text

- Denoted with `alt = "Image description."`.

- Semantic metadata to images.

- Machine-readable + accessible:

  - Search engines / parsers

  - Assistive technologies-friendly (e.g., screen readers)

---

# A simple formula for writing alt text

> alt = "**Chart type** of **type of data** where **reason for including chart**"

by Amy Cesal 

.footenote[
  Source: [DataViz Society/Nightingale](https://medium.com/nightingale/writing-alt-text-for-data-visualization-2a218ef43f81)
]

---

# Example

.pull-left[
![Bar chart of gun murders per 100,000 people where America’s murder rate is 6 times worse than Canada, and 30 times Australia.](https://miro.medium.com/max/1050/1*uE_oJheTzFwFbwkorxj64A.png)
]

--

.pull-right[
> alt = "Bar chart of gun murders per 100,000 people where America’s murder rate is 6 times worse than Canada, and 30 times Australia."
]

.footenote[
  Source: [DataViz Society/Nightingale](https://medium.com/nightingale/writing-alt-text-for-data-visualization-2a218ef43f81)
]

# Faceting

.panelset[
.panel[.panel-name[Plot]
```{r ref.label = "penguins2", echo = FALSE, warning = FALSE, out.width = "70%", fig.width = 8}
```
]
.panel[.panel-name[Code]

```{r penguins2, fig.show = "hide"}
library(palmerpenguins)

ggplot(
  data = penguins,
  mapping = aes(
    x = bill_depth_mm, y = bill_length_mm,
    color = species
  )
) +
  geom_point() +
  facet_wrap(~species) +
  labs(
    title = "Bill depth and length",
    subtitle = "Dimensions for Adelie, Chinstrap, and Gentoo Penguins",
    x = "Bill depth (mm)", y = "Bill length (mm)",
    color = "Species"
  )
```
]
]

---

# Sonify by group
.pull-left[

```{r eval = FALSE}
library(tidyverse)

penguins %>%
  filter(species == "Adelie") %>%
  with(., sonify::sonify(x = bill_depth_mm, y = bill_length_mm))
```

]


.pull-right[

```{r eval = FALSE}
library(tidyverse)

penguins %>%
  filter(species == "Chinstrap") %>%
  with(., sonify::sonify(x = bill_depth_mm, y = bill_length_mm))
```

]
